sols:
The Intermediate Value Theorem states:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
For any real numbers \emph{a} \textless{} \emph{b}, and for any function

$f: [a,b]Â \to \mathbb{R},$

if \emph{f} is continuous on the interval {[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, then
for every real number \emph{y} between \emph{f}(\emph{a}) and
\emph{f}(\emph{b}), there exists a real number \emph{c} in the interval
{[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]} such that \emph{f}(\emph{c})=\emph{y}.
\end{description}

We can usually spot implications in theorems by the use of the word
\emph{then}. So here we have that the statement \emph{A} is

\[\displaystyle A\] = \emph{$f$ is a continuous function on the interval}
{[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, \emph{with} \emph{a} \textless{} \emph{b}. and
the conclusion of the theorem is statement \emph{B}

\[\displaystyle B\] = \emph{for all real numbers y between $f$(a) and $f$(b)
there exists a real number c in the interval {[}a, b {]} such that $f$(c)
= y}.

And so the Intermediate Value Theorem is simply the statement

\[\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B\] And its negation is the statement

\[\displaystyle
A \land \lnot B\]

We'll need the negation of statement \emph{B} for this:

\[\displaystyle \lnot B\] = \emph{there exists a real number y between
$f$(a) and $f$(b) such that for all real number c in the interval {[}a, b
{]} we have $f$(c) $\neq$ y}.

And so the negation is

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\emph{There exists a continuous function $f$ on the interval}
{[}\emph{a},\emph{b} {]}, \emph{with} \emph{a} \textless{} \emph{b} such
that there exists a real number y between $f$(a) and $f$(b) such that for
all real number c in the interval {[}a, b {]} we have $f$(c) $\neq$ y''.
\end{description}
hints:
A theorem is always a statement of the type \emph{A} $\Rightarrow$
\emph{B} and since we have the equivalence

\[\displaystyle
A \Rightarrow B \equiv \lnot A \lor B\] we can deduce that the negation
of such a statement is

\begin{align*}
\lnot(A \Rightarrow B) &\equiv \lnot(\lnot A \lor B)\\
&\equiv A \land \lnot B
\end{align*} Or in plain English: the negation of \emph{A} implies
\emph{B} is when \emph{A} is true and \emph{B} isn't.

The previous hints claims that a theorem is of the type \emph{A}
$\Rightarrow$ \emph{B}. Can you identify each of \emph{A} and \emph{B}?
